CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

1. Electron-rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene (BDTT)
2. Pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione (DPP)
3. Thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione (TPD)
4. [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester (PC71BM)
5. Electron-deficient units
6. Low-band-gap polymers
7. Two different electron-rich units
8. Two different electron-deficient units

Note: The paragraph mentions "two different electron-deficient units" and "one electron-rich unit and two different electron-deficient units," but it does not explicitly state the names of the specific electron-deficient units other than DPP and TPD. Therefore, I assumed that the paragraph is referring to these two units as examples of electron-deficient units. If there are other electron-deficient units mentioned in the context of the paragraph, then those should also be identified as separate entities.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. PBDTT
2. DPP
3. TPD
4. PC71BM
5. Low-band-gap polymers (not a specific material name)
6. Two different electron-deficient units (assuming DPP and TPD)

So the final answer is: PBDTT, DPP, TPD, PC71BM, Two different electron-deficient units (DPP and TPD).

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDTT |
| DPP |
| TPD |
| PC71BM |
| Two different electron-deficient units (DPP and TPD) |

Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

1. PBDTT: electron-rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene
2. DPP: pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione
3. TPD: thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione
4. PC71BM: [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester
5. J SC: short-circuit current density
6. BDTT-DPP75-TPD25: random terpolymer with a ratio of 75% DPP and 25% TPD
7. BDTT-DPP10-TPD90: random terpolymer with a ratio of 10% DPP and 90% TPD
8. BDTT-DPP90-TPD10: random terpolymer with a ratio of 90% DPP and 10% TPD
9. BDTT-DPP75-TPD25: low-band-gap polymer for BHJ-type PSCs
10. BHJ: bulk-heterojunction
11. PSCs: polymer solar cells
12. D-A: donor-acceptor
13. PCs: polymers
14. C 71 BM: [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester (same as PC71BM)
15. BDTT-DPP25-TPD75: random terpolymer with a ratio of 25% DPP and 75% TPD
16. BDTT-DPP10-TPD90: random terpolymer with a ratio of 10% DPP and 90% TPD (same as above)
17. random terpolymers: polymers made up of three different monomers
18. copolymerization: process of polymerizing two or more monomers together
19. electron-deficient units: units that withdraw electrons
20. electron-rich units: units that donate electrons.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. PBDTT
2. DPP
3. TPD
4. PC71BM
5. J SC
6. BDTT-DPP75-TPD25
7. BDTT-DPP10-TPD90
8. BDTT-DPP90-TPD10
9. BDTT-DPP25-TPD75
10. low-band-gap polymers
11. [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester (PC71BM)
12. random terpolymers
13. electron-deficient units
14. electron-rich units.

Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A new series of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) conjugated random terpolymers ( PBDTT-DPP-TPD ) were synthesized from electron - rich thienyl-substituted benzo[1,2b:4,5-b′]dithiophene ( BDTT ) , in conjugation with two electron - deficient units , pyrrolo [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione ( DPP ) and thieno [3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione ( TPD ) , of different electron - withdrawing strengths. The optical properties of these random terpolymers can be easily controlled by tuning the ratio between DPP and TPD ; an increase in TPD induced increased absorption between 400 and 650 nm and a lower highest occupied molecular orbital energy level , while higher DPP contents resulted in stronger absorption between 600 and 900 nm. The best power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of 6.33% was obtained from PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 with [6,6]-phenyl-C 71 -butyric acid methyl ester ( PC71BM ) due to the improved light absorption and thus a short - circuit current density ( J SC ) higher than 16 mA / cm^2. Interestingly , the trend observed in the PCE values differed from that of optical behavior of the PBDTT-DPP-TPD in terms of the DPP to TPD ratio , showing nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% . Density functional theory calculations showed that the small portions of strong electron - withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 could provide trap sites , which suppress efficient charge transfer. In contrast , for PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25 , the effect of minor portions of TPD on electron density distribution was found to be minimal. In addition , the polymer packing and nanomorphology were investigated by grazing - incidence X-ray scattering and atomic force microscopy. The findings suggested that controlling the ratio of electron - deficient units in the random terpolymers is critical for optimizing their performance in polymer solar cells because it affects the polymer packing structure , the optical and electrical properties , and the electron distribution in the polymers . Low-band-gap polymers for bulk - heterojunction (BHJ)-type polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have been studied intensively with the aim of matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and thus harvesting more photon flux , to produce efficiencies greater than 7-9 % . 1-9 In most cases , low-band-gap polymers achieved by the donor - acceptor ( D-A ) approach do not show broad absorption , but instead the absorption maxima are redshifted , decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent. 10-13 One promising approach toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum is to develop random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron - rich units and one electron - deficient unit 14-16 or one electron - rich unit and two different electron - deficient units. 17-22 The judicious selection of two different electrondeficient or - rich groups with different electron - withdrawing or - donating strengths is critical to achieve complementary and broad visible light absorption , thus maximizing photon harvesting. However , successful examples of random terpolymers with broad light absorption and high efficiency are limited.

Let's think step by step.

1. Power conversion efficiency (PCE) of PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25: 6.33%
2. Short-circuit current density (J SC) of PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25: higher than 16 mA / cm^2
3. Optical properties:
   - Absorption between 400 and 650 nm: increased with an increase in TPD
   - Absorption between 600 and 900 nm: stronger with higher DPP contents
   - Highest occupied molecular orbital energy level: lower with an increase in TPD
4. Density functional theory calculations:
   - Electron density distribution: minimal effect with higher TPD contents in PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 and PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10
   - Trap sites: provided by small portions of strong electron-withdrawing DPP in PBDTT-DPP25-TPD75 and PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25
5. Polymer packing and nanomorphology:
   - Critical for optimizing performance in polymer solar cells
   - Affects the polymer packing structure, optical and electrical properties, and electron distribution in the polymers
6. Low-band-gap polymers for BHJ-type PSCs:
   - Aimed at matching a greater part of the solar spectrum and harvesting more photon flux
   - Efficiencies greater than 7-9 %
7. Absorption maxima in low-band-gap polymers:
   - Redshifted, decreasing the number of absorbed photons in the visible region and ultimately limiting the achievable photocurrent
8. Approaches toward broadening the absorption of the solar spectrum:
   - Developing random terpolymers based on the copolymerization of two different electron-rich units and one electron-deficient unit or one electron-rich unit and two different electron-deficient units
9. Critical factors for achieving complementary and broad visible light absorption:
   - Judicious selection of two different electron-deficient or -rich groups with different electron-withdrawing or -donating strengths.

No specific numerical values are mentioned for the other material properties.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Power conversion efficiency (PCE) of PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25: 6.33%
2. Short-circuit current density (J SC) of PBDTT-DPP75-TPD25: higher than 16 mA / cm^2
3. Optical properties:
   - Absorption between 400 and 650 nm: increases with an increase in TPD
   - Absorption between 600 and 900 nm: stronger with higher DPP contents
   - Highest occupied molecular orbital energy level: lower with an increase in TPD
4. Electron density distribution: minimal effect with higher TPD contents in PBDTT-DPP10-TPD90 and PBDTT-DPP90-TPD10
5. PCE of low-band-gap polymers for BHJ-type PSCs: greater than 7-9 %
6. Joule scattering current density: not mentioned in the text.
